title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — In the cauldron of a tied playoff series, legends are born. On this night, it was Patrick Ewing who authored a masterpiece for the ages, carrying the New York Knicks to a brutal 92-90 victory over the Indiana Pacers with a performance that defied logic and time.

The final score was a mere formality, a footnote to Ewing’s historic 44-point eruption. From the opening tip, this was a one-man war waged in the painted area. The Pacers threw bodies at him—Davis, Smits, Mullin—but Ewing was an unstoppable force of mid-range jumpers and powerful post moves. Each possession was a methodical dissection, with the ball finding its way to the franchise cornerstone, who delivered with cold-blooded efficiency.

Indiana, led by Reggie Miller’s 21 points, fought valiantly. Every time the Knicks threatened to pull away, the Pacers clawed back, their defense straining against the tidal wave of Ewing’s dominance. The game hung in the balance until the final, frantic seconds, the outcome resting entirely on the shoulders of the man who had willed his team this far.

When the final horn sounded, the collective exhale from Madison Square Garden could be felt 700 miles away. This was not a win; it was a heist. Ewing didn’t just score points; he shouldered the hopes of an entire city and carried them to a critical road victory. In a series defined by grit over glamour, Patrick Ewing provided a towering, unforgettable lesson in superstar will, securing his legacy with one of the greatest scoring barrages in playoff history.
